summary: SN 3:11  Jaṭila Sutta | Coiled-hair Ascetics  —  How to know another person’s character.

summary: SN 3:23  Loka Sutta | (Qualities of) the World  —  Greed, aversion, and delusion bring harm, stress, and discomfort.

summary: SN 3:24  Issattha Sutta | Archery Skills  —  Where should a gift be given? A gift given where bears great fruit?

summary: SN 3:25  Pabbatopama Sutta | The Simile of the Mountains  —  Aging and death are rolling in, like mountains rolling in from all four directions.

summary: SN 9:11  Ayoniso-manasikāra Sutta | Inappropriate Attention  —  A deva counsels a monk who spends his meditation engaged in wrong resolves.

summary: SN 9:14  Padumapuppha Sutta | The Thief of a Scent  —  A deva warns a monk who sniffs the scent of a lotus.

summary: SN 11:3  Dhajagga Sutta | The Top of the Standard  —  How to ward off fear when practicing alone in the wilderness.

summary: SN 11:5  Subhāsita-jaya Sutta | Victory Through What is Well Spoken  —  How to deal wisely with angry fools.

summary: SN 11:14  Daḷidda Sutta | Poor  —  People are reborn, not in line with their past status, but in line with their actions.

title: SN 11:15  Rāmaṇeyyaka Sutta | A Delightful Place
summary: SN 11:15  Rāmaṇeyyaka Sutta | A Delightful Place  —  Delightful human beings are more delightful than delightful places.

title: SN 11:22  Dubbaṇṇiya Sutta | Ugly
summary: SN 11:22  Dubbaṇṇiya Sutta | Ugly  —  Sakka gets rid of an anger-eating yakkha.

title: SN 11:24  Accaya Sutta | A Transgression
summary: SN 11:24  Accaya Sutta | A Transgression  —  Admit your transgressions, and pardon those who admit theirs.

title: SN 12:2  Paṭiccasamuppāda Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of Dependent Co-arising
summary: SN 12:2  Paṭiccasamuppāda Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of Dependent Co-arising  —  The factors of dependent co-arising defined.

title: SN 12:10  Gotama Sutta | About Gotama
summary: SN 12:10  Gotama Sutta | About Gotama  —  The Buddha describes how he contemplated dependent co-arising prior to his awakening.

title: SN 12:11  Āhāra Sutta | Nutriment
summary: SN 12:11  Āhāra Sutta | Nutriment  —  This discourse incorporates the teaching on the four nutriments (see SN 12:63–64) into the pattern for dependent co-arising, placing them in the position usually occupied by clinging: after craving and before becoming.

title: SN 12:12  Phagguna Sutta | To Phagguna
summary: SN 12:12  Phagguna Sutta | To Phagguna  —  A monk tries to understand the factors of dependent co-arising in terms of who does them. The Buddha shows why this is an invalid way of interpreting them.

title: SN 12:15  Kaccānagotta Sutta | To Kaccāna Gotta
summary: SN 12:15  Kaccānagotta Sutta | To Kaccāna Gotta  —  The Buddha describes the highest level of right view, in which the mind abandons thoughts of existence and non-existence, and sees all arising and passing away as stress (dukkha).

title: SN 12:17  Acela Sutta | To the Clothless Ascetic
summary: SN 12:17  Acela Sutta | To the Clothless Ascetic  —  How dependent co-arising avoids answering questions as to whether pain is self-made, other-made, both self-made and other-made, or spontaneously arisen.

title: SN 12:18  Timbarukkha Sutta | To Timbarukkha
summary: SN 12:18  Timbarukkha Sutta | To Timbarukkha  —  This sutta is similar to the preceding one, with the difference that the questions about pain in the preceding sutta are here expanded to include pleasure as well.

title: SN 12:19  Bāla-paṇḍita Sutta | The Fool & the Wise Person
summary: SN 12:19  Bāla-paṇḍita Sutta | The Fool & the Wise Person  —  What is the difference between a fool and a wise person when both are sensitive to pleasure and pain?

title: SN 12:20  Paccaya Sutta | Requisite Conditions
summary: SN 12:20  Paccaya Sutta | Requisite Conditions  —  The Buddha lists the questions that hold no interest for a person who has seen dependent co-arising and dependently co-arisen phenomena as they have come to be.

title: SN 12:23  Upanisa Sutta | Prerequisites
summary: SN 12:23  Upanisa Sutta | Prerequisites  —  How ignorance, in leading to suffering, can lead beyond suffering to conviction and, based on conviction, to release and to the knowledge of the ending of suffering.

title: SN 12:25  Bhūmija Sutta | To Bhūmija
summary: SN 12:25  Bhūmija Sutta | To Bhūmija  —  Pleasure and pain are dependent on contact, as are doctrines that would hold that they are self-made, other-made, both self-made and other-made, or spontaneously arisen.

title: SN 12:31  Bhūtamidaṁ Sutta | This Has Come Into Being
summary: SN 12:31  Bhūtamidaṁ Sutta | This Has Come Into Being  —  At the Buddha’s request, Ven. Sāriputta explains a verse from the Sutta Nipāta (5:1) on what it means to have fathomed the Dhamma.

title: SN 12:35  Avijjāpaccaya Sutta | From Ignorance as a Requisite Condition
summary: SN 12:35  Avijjāpaccaya Sutta | From Ignorance as a Requisite Condition  —  The Buddha refuses to answer the question of whether there is anyone or anything lying behind the processes described in dependent co-arising.

title: SN 12:38  Cetanā Sutta | Intention
summary: SN 12:38  Cetanā Sutta | Intention  —  This discourse describes the link between fabrications and consciousness in dependent co-arising, and shows how intention and underlying obsessions—with ignorance of the four noble truths being the basis for all obsessions—play a role in constructing awareness of the present moment.

title: SN 12:44  Loka Sutta | The World
summary: SN 12:44  Loka Sutta | The World  —  The Buddha uses dependent co-arising to explain the origination and ending of the world of the six senses.

title: SN 12:46  Aññatara Sutta | A Certain Brahman
summary: SN 12:46  Aññatara Sutta | A Certain Brahman  —  Is the one who acts the same one who experiences the results of the act?

title: SN 12:48  Lokāyatika Sutta | The Cosmologist
summary: SN 12:48  Lokāyatika Sutta | The Cosmologist  —  Dependent co-arising avoids answering questions that lie at the basis of cosmology: Does everything exist? Does everything not exist? Is everything a Oneness? Is everything a plurality?

title: SN 12:51  Parivīmaṁsa Sutta | Investigating
summary: SN 12:51  Parivīmaṁsa Sutta | Investigating  —  How to investigate dependent co-arising so as to lead to the ending of suffering and stress.

title: SN 12:52  Upādāna Sutta | Clinging
summary: SN 12:52  Upādāna Sutta | Clinging  —  Focusing on the allure of the objects of clinging leads to stress. Focusing on their drawbacks leads to the ending of stress. This sutta illustrates this principle with the analogy of feeding and not feeding a large fire.

title: SN 12:55  Mahārukkha Sutta | The Great Tree
summary: SN 12:55  Mahārukkha Sutta | The Great Tree  —  Uprooting clinging and craving is like uprooting a great tree.

title: SN 12:61  Assutavā Sutta | Uninstructed (1)
summary: SN 12:61  Assutavā Sutta | Uninstructed (1)  —  People cling more readily to the mind than to the body, even though the mind is much more changeable than the body.

title: SN 12:62  Assutavā Sutta | Uninstructed (2)
summary: SN 12:62  Assutavā Sutta | Uninstructed (2)  —  This sutta builds on the previous one, showing how to develop dispassion for the mind through a contemplation of feeling.

title: SN 12:63  Puttamaṁsa Sutta | A Son’s Flesh
summary: SN 12:63  Puttamaṁsa Sutta | A Son’s Flesh  —  A meditation on inter-relatedness, showing with four striking similes the suffering inherent in everything the body and mind depend upon for nourishment.

title: SN 12:64  Atthi Rāga Sutta | Where There is Passion
summary: SN 12:64  Atthi Rāga Sutta | Where There is Passion  —  With two striking similes, this sutta describes what happens when consciousness, through passion, lands and grows on any of its four nutriments, and what happens when it abandons that passion.

title: SN 12:65  Nagara Sutta | The City
summary: SN 12:65  Nagara Sutta | The City  —  The Buddha describes his discovery of dependent co-arising with the simile of a man finding an ancient road to a long-abandoned city.

title: SN 12:66  Sammasa Sutta | Scrutiny
summary: SN 12:66  Sammasa Sutta | Scrutiny  —  How to scrutinize the allures of the world so as not to suffer.

title: SN 12:67  Naḷakalāpiyo Sutta | Sheaves of Reeds
summary: SN 12:67  Naḷakalāpiyo Sutta | Sheaves of Reeds  —  Ven. Sāriputta analyses the factors of dependent co-arising down to a mutual dependence between consciousness on the one hand, and name-&-form on the other.

title: SN 12:68  Kosambī Sutta | At Kosambī
summary: SN 12:68  Kosambī Sutta | At Kosambī  —  Ven. Nārada uses the simile of the well to describe the difference between stream-entry and arahantship.

title: SN 12:69  Upayanti Sutta | Rises
summary: SN 12:69  Upayanti Sutta | Rises  —  The rising and ebbing of ignorance, and its effect on the other factors of dependent co-arising, is compared to the rising and ebbing of the ocean, and its effect on rivers and lakes.

title: SN 12:70  Susima Sutta | About Susima
summary: SN 12:70  Susima Sutta | About Susima  —  A wanderer from another sect attempts to “steal” the Dhamma, but ends up actually awakening to it.

title: SN 13:1  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail
summary: SN 13:1  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail  —  The Buddha uses a striking simile to make the point that the suffering remaining for a person who has reached stream-entry is much, much less than the suffering remaining for someone who hasn’t.

title: SN 13:2  Pokkharaṇī Sutta | The Pond
summary: SN 13:2  Pokkharaṇī Sutta | The Pond  —  The Buddha uses another simile to make the same point as in the preceding sutta.

title: SN 13:8  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean
summary: SN 13:8  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean  —  Yet another simile to make the same point.

title: SN 14:11  Sattadhātu Sutta | Seven Properties
summary: SN 14:11  Sattadhātu Sutta | Seven Properties  —  An alternative to the standard list of the levels of concentration, in which concentration attainments are described in terms of seven properties.

title: SN 15:3  Assu Sutta | Tears
summary: SN 15:3  Assu Sutta | Tears  —  Which is greater: the water in all the oceans or the tears you have shed while wandering through transmigration?

title: SN 15:5  Pabbata Sutta | A Mountain
summary: SN 15:5  Pabbata Sutta | A Mountain  —  How long is an eon? The Buddha gives a simile.

title: SN 15:6  Sāsapa Sutta | Mustard Seed
summary: SN 15:6  Sāsapa Sutta | Mustard Seed  —  How long is an eon? The Buddha gives another simile.

title: SN 15:8  Gangā Sutta | The Ganges
summary: SN 15:8  Gangā Sutta | The Ganges  —  How many eons have gone by?

title: SN 15:9  Daṇḍa Sutta | The Stick
summary: SN 15:9  Daṇḍa Sutta | The Stick  —  The randomness of transmigration.

title: SN 15:10  Puggala Sutta | Person
summary: SN 15:10  Puggala Sutta | Person  —  In this course of transmigrating, one person would leave behind a heap of bones as large as a mountain—if there were someone to collect the bones and the collection were not destroyed.

title: SN 15:11  Duggata Sutta | Fallen on Hard Times
summary: SN 15:11  Duggata Sutta | Fallen on Hard Times  —  A contemplation to keep your compassion from being condescending: When you see someone who has fallen on hard times, you should conclude that you have experienced just that sort of thing in the long course of transmigration.

title: SN 15:12  Sukhita Sutta | Happy
summary: SN 15:12  Sukhita Sutta | Happy  —  A contemplation to prevent envy and resentment of others’ good fortune:When you see someone who is well-provided in life, you should conclude that you have experienced just that sort of thing in the long course of transmigration.

title: SN 15:13  Tiṁsa Sutta | Thirty
summary: SN 15:13  Tiṁsa Sutta | Thirty  —  The Buddha leads a group of monks to awakening by teaching that the blood they have shed in the course of transmigration—through being executed for crimes or through being slaughtered as animals—is greater than the water in all the oceans.

title: SN 15:14  Mātu Sutta (SN 15:14–19) | Mother
summary: SN 15:14  Mātu Sutta (SN 15:14–19) | Mother  —  It would be hard to find someone who has not been a close relative in the long course of transmigration.

title: SN 16:2  Anottāpī Sutta | Without Compunction
summary: SN 16:2  Anottāpī Sutta | Without Compunction  —  What it means to be ardent and to have compunction.

title: SN 16:5  Jiṇṇa Sutta | Old
summary: SN 16:5  Jiṇṇa Sutta | Old  —  Why Ven. Mahā Kassapa continued to practice austerities even when he was old.

title: SN 16:11  Cīvara Sutta | The Robe
summary: SN 16:11  Cīvara Sutta | The Robe  —  Ven. Mahā Kassapa tells of how he went forth and first met the Buddha.

title: SN 16:13  Saddhammapaṭirūpaka Sutta | A Counterfeit of the True Dhamma
summary: SN 16:13  Saddhammapaṭirūpaka Sutta | A Counterfeit of the True Dhamma  —  What it means for the True Dhamma to disappear.

title: SN 17:3  Kumma Sutta | The Turtle
summary: SN 17:3  Kumma Sutta | The Turtle  —  A simile for the dangers posed by gains, offerings, and fame.

title: SN 17:5  Kaṁsaḷakā Sutta | The Dung Beetle
summary: SN 17:5  Kaṁsaḷakā Sutta | The Dung Beetle  —  Another simile for the dangers posed by gains, offerings, and fame.

title: SN 17:8  Sigala Sutta | The Jackal
summary: SN 17:8  Sigala Sutta | The Jackal  —  Yet another simile for the same dangers.

title: SN 20:2  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail
summary: SN 20:2  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail  —  Few are the beings reborn among human beings. Far more are those reborn elsewhere.

title: SN 20:4  Okkhā Sutta | Serving Dishes
summary: SN 20:4  Okkhā Sutta | Serving Dishes  —  The development of goodwill, even for a moment, is more fruitful than many lavish gifts of food.

title: SN 20:5  Satti Sutta | The Spear
summary: SN 20:5  Satti Sutta | The Spear  —  Goodwill protects the mind from being deranged.

title: SN 20:6  Dhanuggaha Sutta | The Archer
summary: SN 20:6  Dhanuggaha Sutta | The Archer  —  Life rushes to its end faster than the speed of the sun and moon.

title: SN 20:7  Āṇi Sutta | The Peg
summary: SN 20:7  Āṇi Sutta | The Peg  —  How “improvements” to the Dhamma make it disappear.

title: SN 21:1  Kolita Sutta | Kolita
summary: SN 21:1  Kolita Sutta | Kolita  —  The meaning of noble silence.

title: SN 21:2  Upatissa Sutta | About Upatissa (Sāriputta)
summary: SN 21:2  Upatissa Sutta | About Upatissa (Sāriputta)  —  When there is no I-making or mine-making, there is no reason for grief.

title: SN 21:3  Ghaṭa Sutta | The Barrel
summary: SN 21:3  Ghaṭa Sutta | The Barrel  —  Ven. Sāriputta praises Ven. Moggallāna for his psychic powers; Ven. Moggallāna praises Ven. Sāriputta for his discernment.

title: SN 21:6  Bhaddiya Sutta | Bhaddiya
summary: SN 21:6  Bhaddiya Sutta | Bhaddiya  —  Greatness is a matter of the mind, not of the physique.

title: SN 21:9  Tissa Sutta | Tissa
summary: SN 21:9  Tissa Sutta | Tissa  —  A monk makes himself miserable because he can’t stand being admonished.

title: SN 21:10  Theranāma Sutta | (A Monk) by the Name of Elder (On Solitude)
summary: SN 21:10  Theranāma Sutta | (A Monk) by the Name of Elder (On Solitude)  —  The true meaning of living in solitude.

title: SN 22:1  Nakulapitar Sutta | To Nakulapitar
summary: SN 22:1  Nakulapitar Sutta | To Nakulapitar  —  What it means to be afflicted in body but not afflicted in mind.

title: SN 22:2  Devadaha Sutta | At Devadaha
summary: SN 22:2  Devadaha Sutta | At Devadaha  —  Ven. Sāriputta’s recommendations for how to explain the Dhamma to people new to it.

title: SN 22:3  Haliddikāni Sutta | To Haliddikāni
summary: SN 22:3  Haliddikāni Sutta | To Haliddikāni  —  Ven. Mahā Kaccāna explains a verse from the Aṭṭhaka Vagga (Sn 4:9).

title: SN 22:5  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration
summary: SN 22:5  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration  —  When the mind is concentrated, it can discern the origination and disappearance of the aggregates.

title: SN 22:18  Hetu Sutta | Cause (1)
summary: SN 22:18  Hetu Sutta | Cause (1)  —  How can anything whose cause is inconstant be constant?

title: SN 22:19  Hetu Sutta | Cause (2)
summary: SN 22:19  Hetu Sutta | Cause (2)  —  How can anything whose cause is stressful be easeful?

title: SN 22:20  Hetu Sutta | Cause (3)
summary: SN 22:20  Hetu Sutta | Cause (3)  —  How can anything whose cause is not-self be self?

title: SN 22:22  Bhāra Sutta | The Burden
summary: SN 22:22  Bhāra Sutta | The Burden  —  The Buddha explains the burden, the carrier of the burden, the taking up of the burden, and the casting off of the burden.

title: SN 22:23  Pariñña Sutta | Comprehension
summary: SN 22:23  Pariñña Sutta | Comprehension  —  The four noble truths are to be comprehended. This sutta explains what comprehension means.

title: SN 22:36  Bhikkhu Sutta | The Monk
summary: SN 22:36  Bhikkhu Sutta | The Monk  —  If you are obsessed with the aggregates, you define yourself by them and limit yourself to them. If you are not obsessed with them, you are unlimited and undefined.

title: SN 22:39  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (1)
summary: SN 22:39  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (1)  —  Toward the end of his life, the Buddha stated that the proper way to pay homage to him was to “practice the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma.” This sutta explains what that means, in terms of cultivating disenchantment (nibbidā).

title: SN 22:40  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (2)
summary: SN 22:40  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (2)  —  Toward the end of his life, the Buddha stated that the proper way to pay homage to him was to “practice the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma.” This sutta explains what that means, in terms of focusing on inconstancy (anicca).

title: SN 22:41  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (3)
summary: SN 22:41  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (3)  —  Toward the end of his life, the Buddha stated that the proper way to pay homage to him was to “practice the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma.” This sutta explains what that means, in terms of focusing on stress/suffering (dukkha).

title: SN 22:42  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (4)
summary: SN 22:42  Anudhamma Sutta | In Accordance with the Dhamma (4)  —  Toward the end of his life, the Buddha stated that the proper way to pay homage to him was to “practice the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma.” This sutta explains what that means, in terms of focusing on not-self (anattā).

title: SN 22:47  Samanupassanā Sutta | Assumptions
summary: SN 22:47  Samanupassanā Sutta | Assumptions  —  How the assumption “I am” colors the experience of the five physical senses, and how that assumption can be overcome.

title: SN 22:48  Khandha Sutta | Aggregates
summary: SN 22:48  Khandha Sutta | Aggregates  —  The difference between aggregates and clinging-aggregates.

title: SN 22:53  Upaya Sutta | Attached
summary: SN 22:53  Upaya Sutta | Attached  —  The bases on which consciousness lands and grows.

title: SN 22:54  Bīja Sutta | Means of Propagation
summary: SN 22:54  Bīja Sutta | Means of Propagation  —  This sutta explains the principle from the preceding sutta with an example from plant propagation.

title: SN 22:55  Udāna Sutta | Exclamation
summary: SN 22:55  Udāna Sutta | Exclamation  —  How the contemplation of the theme, “It should not be, it should not occur to me; it will not be, it will not occur to me” can lead to awakening.

title: SN 22:56  Parivaṭṭa Sutta | The (Fourfold) Round
summary: SN 22:56  Parivaṭṭa Sutta | The (Fourfold) Round  —  The Buddha’s fourfold knowledge concerning each of the five aggregates: knowledge of the aggregate itself, of its origination, of its cessation, and of the path of practice leading to its cessation.

title: SN 22:57  Sattaṭṭhāna Sutta | Seven Bases
summary: SN 22:57  Sattaṭṭhāna Sutta | Seven Bases  —  The Buddha recommends knowing each aggregate in terms of the aggregate itself, its origination, its cessation, the path of practice leading to its cessation, its allure, its drawbacks, and the escape from it. He also describes three ways of investigating the aggregates: in terms of the six sense media, in terms of properties, and in terms of dependent co-arising.

title: SN 22:58  Buddha Sutta | Awakened
summary: SN 22:58  Buddha Sutta | Awakened  —  Some schools of Buddhism teach that there is a qualitative difference between the liberation of a Buddha and that of an arahant disciple — namely, that a Buddha awakens to one level of truth, whereas an arahant awakens to another. This sutta shows that the Buddha saw the distinction in different terms.

title: SN 22:59  Pañca Sutta | The Five (Brethren)
summary: SN 22:59  Pañca Sutta | The Five (Brethren)  —  This discourse is also known as the Anatta-lakkhaṇa Sutta, the Discourse on the Not-self Characteristic, although this title is not found in the Canon. According to Mv I, this was the first of the Buddha’s discourses during which his listeners became arahants.

title: SN 22:60  Mahāli Sutta | To Mahāli
summary: SN 22:60  Mahāli Sutta | To Mahāli  —  Sometimes it is said that people are attached to things because they believe those things to have an inherent essence or existence. Here, however, the Buddha points out that people are attached to things because they pay attention to the pleasure offered by those things, and ignore the stress they cause.

title: SN 22:76  Arahanta Sutta | Arahants
summary: SN 22:76  Arahanta Sutta | Arahants  —  How happy are the arahants!

title: SN 22:78  Sīha Sutta | The Lion
summary: SN 22:78  Sīha Sutta | The Lion  —  The terror that the Buddha’s teaching on the aggregates inspires in the heavenly worlds.

title: SN 22:79  Khajjanīya Sutta | Chewed Up
summary: SN 22:79  Khajjanīya Sutta | Chewed Up  —  This sutta defines the aggregates in terms of verbs. It also shows how, when you feed on the aggregates through clinging, they chew you up in return.

title: SN 22:80  Piṇḍolya Sutta | Almsgoers
summary: SN 22:80  Piṇḍolya Sutta | Almsgoers  —  After having dismissed the monks, the Buddha returns to teach them out of compassion for the monks newly gone-forth.

title: SN 22:81  Pālileyyaka Sutta | At Pālileyyaka
summary: SN 22:81  Pālileyyaka Sutta | At Pālileyyaka  —  After the Buddha has gone into seclusion, Ven. Ānanda leads a group of monks to visit him and to hear the Dhamma. The Buddha responds by addressing the question, “Knowing in what way, seeing in what way, does one without delay put an end to effluents?”

title: SN 22:82  Puṇṇama Sutta | The Full-moon Night
summary: SN 22:82  Puṇṇama Sutta | The Full-moon Night  —  A thorough discussion of issues related to the five aggregates. Toward the end of the discussion, a monk thinks that he has found a loophole in the teaching. The way the Buddha handles this incident shows the proper use of the teachings on the aggregates: not as a metaphysical theory, but as a tool for gaining dispassion for clinging—and, as a result, release.

title: SN 22:83  Ānanda Sutta | Ānanda
summary: SN 22:83  Ānanda Sutta | Ānanda  —  Ven. Ānanda recalls the Dhamma explanation, given by Ven. Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta (see MN 24), that enabled him to break through to the Dhamma.

title: SN 22:84  Tissa Sutta | Tissa
summary: SN 22:84  Tissa Sutta | Tissa  —  The Buddha comforts and encourages one of his cousins who has become dissatisfied with the holy life. He concludes with a simile, comparing the noble eightfold path to a path going through a dense forest (ignorance), a marshy swamp (sensual desires), past a steep drop-off (anger & despair), and finally arriving at a patch of level ground: unbinding.

title: SN 22:85  Yamaka Sutta | To Yamaka
summary: SN 22:85  Yamaka Sutta | To Yamaka  —  Ven. Sāriputta teaches the Dhamma to a monk who has given rise to an evil view: that an arahant, after death, does not exist.

title: SN 22:86  Anurādha Sutta | To Anurādha
summary: SN 22:86  Anurādha Sutta | To Anurādha  —  The Buddha teaches the Dhamma to a monk who thinks that, after death, a Tathāgata can be described as something other than existing, not existing, both, or neither.

title: SN 22:88  Assaji Sutta | To Assaji
summary: SN 22:88  Assaji Sutta | To Assaji  —  The Buddha teaches a sick monk who is concerned that he cannot attain the level of concentration he had before falling ill.

title: SN 22:89  Khemaka Sutta | About Khemaka
summary: SN 22:89  Khemaka Sutta | About Khemaka  —  How a non-returner views the issue of self.

title: SN 22:90  Channa Sutta | To Channa
summary: SN 22:90  Channa Sutta | To Channa  —  Ven. Channa, after having been punished by the Buddha for his stubbornness, has a change of heart and seeks out Ven. Ānanda to hear the Dhamma.

title: SN 22:93  Nadī Sutta | The River
summary: SN 22:93  Nadī Sutta | The River  —  Trying to hold onto the aggregates is like trying to hold onto grasses on the bank of a river as the current is sweeping you away.

title: SN 22:94  Puppha Sutta | Flowers
summary: SN 22:94  Puppha Sutta | Flowers  —  What the Buddha describes as existing and not-existing.

title: SN 22:95  Pheṇa Sutta | Foam
summary: SN 22:95  Pheṇa Sutta | Foam  —  Five vivid similes for the insubstantial nature of the aggregates.

title: SN 22:96  Gomaya Sutta | Cow Dung
summary: SN 22:96  Gomaya Sutta | Cow Dung  —  The Buddha reflects on the transiency of past glory.

title: SN 22:97  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail
summary: SN 22:97  Nakhasikhā Sutta | The Tip of the Fingernail  —  There isn’t even a smidgen of any of the aggregates that lasts for eternity.

title: SN 22:99  Gaddūla Sutta | The Leash (1)
summary: SN 22:99  Gaddūla Sutta | The Leash (1)  —  As long as you cling to the aggregates, you keep running around them, like a dog on a leash, even after the Earth is consumed by flames.

title: SN 22:100  Gaddūla Sutta | The Leash (2)
summary: SN 22:100  Gaddūla Sutta | The Leash (2)  —  As long as you cling to the aggregates, you keep running around them, like a dog on a leash, creating from them many variegated forms of delusion and suffering.

title: SN 22:101  Nava Sutta | The Ship
summary: SN 22:101  Nava Sutta | The Ship  —  Two vivid similes for the practice, one illustrating the principle that results depend, not on wishing, but on actually doing the practice; the other illustrating the gradual nature of progress along the path.

title: SN 22:121  Upādāna Sutta | Clinging
summary: SN 22:121  Upādāna Sutta | Clinging  —  Clinging defined.

title: SN 22:122  Sīlavant Sutta | Virtuous
summary: SN 22:122  Sīlavant Sutta | Virtuous  —  How and why to attend appropriately to the aggregates at various stages of the path, even after full awakening.

title: SN 22:126  Samudaya-dhamma Sutta | Subject to Origination (1)
summary: SN 22:126  Samudaya-dhamma Sutta | Subject to Origination (1)  —  Ignorance defined.

title: SN 22:127  Samudaya-dhamma Sutta | Subject to Origination (2)
summary: SN 22:127  Samudaya-dhamma Sutta | Subject to Origination (2)  —  Clear knowing (vijjā) defined.

title: SN 22:131  Samudaya Sutta | Origination (1)
summary: SN 22:131  Samudaya Sutta | Origination (1)  —  Another definition of ignorance.

title: SN 22:132  Samudaya Sutta | Origination (2)
summary: SN 22:132  Samudaya Sutta | Origination (2)  —  Another definition of clear knowing (vijjā).

title: SN 23:1  Māra Sutta | Mortality
summary: SN 23:1  Māra Sutta | Mortality  —  How to see the aggregates rightly, and the purpose of seeing rightly.

title: SN 23:2  Satta Sutta | A Being
summary: SN 23:2  Satta Sutta | A Being  —  How we define ourselves as “beings,” and how to go beyond that self-definition.

title: SN 25:1  Cakkhu Sutta | The Eye
summary: SN 25:1  Cakkhu Sutta | The Eye  —  The ten suttas in this saṁyutta discuss the different ways that a faith-follower, a Dhamma-follower, and a stream-enterer (see MN 70) understand the inconstancy of different aspects of experience: (1) the six sense bases; (2) their objects; (3) consciousness; (4) contact; (5) feeling; (6) perception; (7) intentions; (8) craving; (9) the six properties (earth, liquid, fire, wind, space, and consciousness); and (10) the five aggregates.

summary: SN 27:1  Cakkhu Sutta | The Eye  —  The ten suttas in this saṁyutta discuss the benefits of overcoming passion-delight (another term for clinging—see SN 22:121) for different aspects of experience: (1) the six sense bases; (2) their objects; (3) consciousness; (4) contact; (5) feeling; (6) perception; (7) intentions; (8) craving; (9) the six properties (earth, liquid, fire, wind, space, and consciousness); and (10) the five aggregates.

title: SN 35:17  No Cedaṁ Sutta | If There Were Not This (1)
summary: SN 35:17  No Cedaṁ Sutta | If There Were Not This (1)  —  How to dwell with unrestricted awareness.

title: SN 35:18  No Cedaṁ Sutta | If There Were Not This (2)
summary: SN 35:18  No Cedaṁ Sutta | If There Were Not This (2)  —  Another way to dwell with unrestricted awareness.

title: SN 35:19  Abhinanda Sutta | Delight (1)
summary: SN 35:19  Abhinanda Sutta | Delight (1)  —  To delight in the senses is to delight in stress.

title: SN 35:20  Abhinanda Sutta | Delight (2)
summary: SN 35:20  Abhinanda Sutta | Delight (2)  —  To delight in the objects of the senses is to delight in stress.

title: SN 35:23  Sabba Sutta | The All
summary: SN 35:23  Sabba Sutta | The All  —  What does the Buddha mean by “the All”?

title: SN 35:24  Pahāna Sutta | For Abandoning
summary: SN 35:24  Pahāna Sutta | For Abandoning  —  What is the “All” that is to be abandoned?

title: SN 35:28  Āditta-pariyāya Sutta | Aflame
summary: SN 35:28  Āditta-pariyāya Sutta | Aflame  —  The Buddha teaches a group of 1,000 monks who formerly worshiped fire. Stating that the six senses and all the processes dependent on them are aflame with the fires of defilement and suffering, he explains how to put the fires out. During his explanation, all 1,000 monks gain awakening.

title: SN 35:63  Migajāla Sutta | To Migajāla
summary: SN 35:63  Migajāla Sutta | To Migajāla  —  How a person living in isolation can still be described as living with a companion, and how a person living near people can still be described as living alone.

title: SN 35:69  Upasena Sutta | Upasena
summary: SN 35:69  Upasena Sutta | Upasena  —  An arahant, bitten by a snake, approaches death with no apparent change in his faculties.

title: SN 35:74  Gilāna Sutta | Ill (1)
summary: SN 35:74  Gilāna Sutta | Ill (1)  —  The Buddha teaches a newly-ordained monk who has fallen ill, leading him to stream-entry.

title: SN 35:75  Gilāna Sutta | Ill (2)
summary: SN 35:75  Gilāna Sutta | Ill (2)  —  The Buddha teaches a newly-ordained monk who has fallen ill, leading him to arahantship.

title: SN 35:80  Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance
summary: SN 35:80  Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance  —  How to reach arahantship by contemplating all the processes of the senses as something separate.

title: SN 35:82  Loka Sutta | The World
summary: SN 35:82  Loka Sutta | The World  —  How the Buddha defines the world.

title: SN 35:85  Suñña Sutta | Empty
summary: SN 35:85  Suñña Sutta | Empty  —  In what way is the world empty?

title: SN 35:88  Puṇṇa Sutta | To Puṇṇa
summary: SN 35:88  Puṇṇa Sutta | To Puṇṇa  —  A monk takes leave of the Buddha to go a country where the inhabitants are reputed to be vicious and rough.

title: SN 35:93  Dvaya Sutta | A Pair
summary: SN 35:93  Dvaya Sutta | A Pair  —  Sensory consciousness is inconstant because the conditions by which it comes into play are inconstant.

title: SN 35:95  Māluṅkyaputta Sutta | To Māluṅkyaputta
summary: SN 35:95  Māluṅkyaputta Sutta | To Māluṅkyaputta  —  An elderly monk asks the Buddha for a brief explanation of the Dhamma that he can put into practice. The Buddha gives him the same instruction that he gives to Bāhiya in Ud 1:10.

title: SN 35:97  Pamādavihārin Sutta | Dwelling in Heedlessness
summary: SN 35:97  Pamādavihārin Sutta | Dwelling in Heedlessness  —  What it means to dwell in heedlessness and to dwell in heedfulness.

title: SN 35:99  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration
summary: SN 35:99  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration  —  What can be seen when the mind is concentrated.

title: SN 35:101  Na Tumhāka Sutta | Not Yours
summary: SN 35:101  Na Tumhāka Sutta | Not Yours  —  “Whatever’s not yours: Let go of it. Your letting go of it will be for your long-term happiness & benefit.”

title: SN 35:115  Mārapāsa Sutta | Māra’s Power
summary: SN 35:115  Mārapāsa Sutta | Māra’s Power  —  What it means to be under Māra’s power and to have escaped that power.

title: SN 35:116  Loka Sutta | Cosmos
summary: SN 35:116  Loka Sutta | Cosmos  —  How to come to the end of the cosmos within.

title: SN 35:117  Kāmaguṇa Sutta | Strings of Sensuality
summary: SN 35:117  Kāmaguṇa Sutta | Strings of Sensuality  —  That dimension is to be experienced where the internal sense media cease and the perception of the external sense media fades away.

title: SN 35:118  Sakka Sutta | To Sakka
summary: SN 35:118  Sakka Sutta | To Sakka  —  Why some beings reach unbinding in the present lifetime and some don’t.

title: SN 35:127  Bhāradvāja Sutta | About Bhāradvāja
summary: SN 35:127  Bhāradvāja Sutta | About Bhāradvāja  —  How do young monks successfully make celibacy a life-long practice?

title: SN 35:134  Devadaha Sutta | At Devadaha
summary: SN 35:134  Devadaha Sutta | At Devadaha  —  Why even those who have attained the lower levels of the noble attainments still have work to do with heedfulness.

title: SN 35:135  Khaṇa Sutta | The Opportunity
summary: SN 35:135  Khaṇa Sutta | The Opportunity  —  The opportunity to practice the holy life is a rare and valuable opportunity.

title: SN 35:136  Rūpārāma Sutta | Delight in Forms
summary: SN 35:136  Rūpārāma Sutta | Delight in Forms  —  What the noble ones have seen runs counter to the views of the world.

title: SN 35:145  Kamma Sutta | Action
summary: SN 35:145  Kamma Sutta | Action  —  New kamma, old kamma, the cessation of kamma, and the path of practice leading to the cessation of kamma.

title: SN 35:153  Indriya Sutta | Faculties
summary: SN 35:153  Indriya Sutta | Faculties  —  What it means to be consummate in faculties.

title: SN 35:187  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean (1)
summary: SN 35:187  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean (1)  —  The six senses are like a dangerous ocean.

title: SN 35:188  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean (2)
summary: SN 35:188  Samudda Sutta | The Ocean (2)  —  The object of the senses are like a dangerous ocean.

title: SN 35:189  Bāḷisika Sutta | The Fisherman
summary: SN 35:189  Bāḷisika Sutta | The Fisherman  —  Agreeable sense objects are like hooks for catching fish.

title: SN 35:190  Khīrarukkha Sutta | The Milk Sap Tree
summary: SN 35:190  Khīrarukkha Sutta | The Milk Sap Tree  —  Passion, aversion, and delusion are like the sap of a tree.

title: SN 35:191  Koṭṭhita Sutta | To Koṭṭhita
summary: SN 35:191  Koṭṭhita Sutta | To Koṭṭhita  —  With what are the senses fettered?

title: SN 35:193  Udāyī Sutta | With Udāyin
summary: SN 35:193  Udāyī Sutta | With Udāyin  —  Why consciousness is not-self.

title: SN 35:197  Āsīvisa Sutta | Vipers
summary: SN 35:197  Āsīvisa Sutta | Vipers  —  A vivid extended metaphor for the dangers of the aggregates, properties, and sense media, and for the path leading to safety from those dangers.

title: SN 35:198  Ratha Sutta | The Chariot
summary: SN 35:198  Ratha Sutta | The Chariot  —  Similes to illustrate three practices: guarding the doors to your sense faculties, knowing moderation in eating, and being devoted to wakefulness.

title: SN 35:199  Kumma Sutta | The Turtle
summary: SN 35:199  Kumma Sutta | The Turtle  —  Just as a jackal can’t harm a turtle who has withdrawn its head and limbs into its shell, Māra can’t find an opening to harm you when you keep your sense doors well guarded.

title: SN 35:200  Dārukkhandha Sutta | The Log
summary: SN 35:200  Dārukkhandha Sutta | The Log  —  The Buddha, seeing a log floating down the river, uses it as an extended metaphor for the dangers faced in the practice.

title: SN 35:202  Avassuta Sutta | Soggy
summary: SN 35:202  Avassuta Sutta | Soggy  —  What does it mean to be soggy inside?

title: SN 35:204  Kiṁsuka Sutta | The Riddle Tree
summary: SN 35:204  Kiṁsuka Sutta | The Riddle Tree  —  A monk asks a number of other monks how to purify his vision of the Dhmma, and receives a variety of answers. The Buddha explains the variety with the simile of the riddle tree.

title: SN 35:205  Vīṇā Sutta | The Lute
summary: SN 35:205  Vīṇā Sutta | The Lute  —  Two similes. The Buddha explains the practice of restraint of the senses with the simile of how to restrain a corn-eating ox, and the search for an “I” in the aggregates with the simile of the king looking for the sound in a lute.

title: SN 35:206  Chappāṇa Sutta | The Six Animals
summary: SN 35:206  Chappāṇa Sutta | The Six Animals  —  Mindfulness of the body provides a firm foundation for practicing restraint of the senses.

title: SN 35:207  Yavakalāpi Sutta | The Sheaf of Barley
summary: SN 35:207  Yavakalāpi Sutta | The Sheaf of Barley  —  The subtle bonds of Māra.

title: SN 36:4  Pātāla Sutta | The Bottomless Chasm
summary: SN 36:4  Pātāla Sutta | The Bottomless Chasm  —  How to find a foothold in the bottomless chasm of physical pain.

title: SN 36:6  Sallattha Sutta | The Arrow
summary: SN 36:6  Sallattha Sutta | The Arrow  —  When you get distraught over physical pain, it’s like having been shot by an arrow and then shooting yourself with a second arrow.

title: SN 36:7  Gelañña Sutta | The Sick Ward
summary: SN 36:7  Gelañña Sutta | The Sick Ward  —  How to approach the time of death mindful and alert.

title: SN 36:11  Rahogata Sutta | Alone
summary: SN 36:11  Rahogata Sutta | Alone  —  Two topics connected through the theme of fabrication: (1) How is it that—even though the Buddha describes feelings as pleasant, painful, and neither pleasant nor pain—he also describes all feelings as stressful? (2) How does progress through the jhānas and formless attainments involve the step-by-step cessation, stilling, and calming of fabrications?

title: SN 36:19  Pañcakaṅga Sutta | Pañcakaṅga
summary: SN 36:19  Pañcakaṅga Sutta | Pañcakaṅga  —  The Buddha explains many ways of analyzing feelings and concludes by showing how to use the pleasures of concentration as a basis for reaching a pleasure—unbinding—that lies beyond feelings.

title: SN 36:21  Sivaka Sutta | To Sivaka
summary: SN 36:21  Sivaka Sutta | To Sivaka  —  Old and new kamma do not override other causal factors operating in the universe—such as those recognized by the medical and physical sciences—but instead find expression within them.

title: SN 36:22  Aṭṭhasata Sutta | The One-Hundred-and-Eight Exposition
summary: SN 36:22  Aṭṭhasata Sutta | The One-Hundred-and-Eight Exposition  —  Various ways of classifying feelings.

title: SN 36:23  Bhikkhu Sutta | To a Certain Bhikkhu
summary: SN 36:23  Bhikkhu Sutta | To a Certain Bhikkhu  —  Feeling, its origination, the path of practice leading to its origination, its cessation of feeling, the path of practice leading to its cessation, its allure, its drawback, and the escape from feeling.

title: SN 36:31  Nirāmisa Sutta | Not of the Flesh
summary: SN 36:31  Nirāmisa Sutta | Not of the Flesh  —  The differences among feelings of the flesh, feelings not of the flesh, and feelings more not of the flesh than not of the flesh.

title: SN 37:34  Vaḍḍhinā Sutta | Growth
summary: SN 37:34  Vaḍḍhinā Sutta | Growth  —  This brief sutta, which encourages education for women, may account for the fact that in the pre-modern world Theravada Buddhist countries had the highest rates of female literacy.

title: SN 38:14  Dukkha Sutta | Stress
summary: SN 38:14  Dukkha Sutta | Stress  —  Ven. Sāriputta defines three types of stressfulness.

title: SN 41:3  Isidatta Sutta | About Isidatta
summary: SN 41:3  Isidatta Sutta | About Isidatta  —  In this sutta, Ven. Isidatta finds himself in an awkward situation: He can answer a question posed by Citta the householder that the more senior monks can’t answer.

title: SN 41:4  Mahaka Sutta | About Mahaka
summary: SN 41:4  Mahaka Sutta | About Mahaka  —  Citta catches sight of a junior monk performing a miracle of psychic power and asks to see more.

title: SN 41:6  Kāmabhū Sutta | With Kāmabhū (On the Cessation of Perception & Feeling)
summary: SN 41:6  Kāmabhū Sutta | With Kāmabhū (On the Cessation of Perception & Feeling)  —  Questions and answers on the topic of the three types of fabrication—bodily, verbal, and mental—as they apply to the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling.

title: SN 41:7  Godatta Sutta | To Godatta (On Awareness-release)
summary: SN 41:7  Godatta Sutta | To Godatta (On Awareness-release)  —  Ven. Godatta questions Citta the householder on the immeasurable awareness-release, the nothingness awareness-release, the emptiness awareness-release, and the themeless awareness-release.

title: SN 41:10  Gilāna Sutta | Sick (Citta the Householder’s Last Hours)
summary: SN 41:10  Gilāna Sutta | Sick (Citta the Householder’s Last Hours)  —  After rejecting a request from devas that he set his mind on becoming a wheel-turning monarch in a future life, Citta the householder teaches his relatives before passing away.

title: SN 42:2  Tālapuṭa Sutta | To Tālapuṭa the Actor
summary: SN 42:2  Tālapuṭa Sutta | To Tālapuṭa the Actor  —  What are the karmic consequences of being an actor who, intoxicated and heedless, tries to make others intoxicated and heedless?

title: SN 42:3  Yodhājīva Sutta | To Yodhājīva (The Professional Warrior)
summary: SN 42:3  Yodhājīva Sutta | To Yodhājīva (The Professional Warrior)  —  What future awaits a soldier who is killed in battle while he is trying to kill others?

title: SN 42:6  Paccha-bhūmika Sutta | (Brahmans) of the Western Land
summary: SN 42:6  Paccha-bhūmika Sutta | (Brahmans) of the Western Land  —  Can prayers and incantations dedicated to a person after death counteract the kamma that that person made when alive?

title: SN 42:7  Desanā Sutta | Teaching
summary: SN 42:7  Desanā Sutta | Teaching  —  Why does the Buddha teach the Dhamma with full attentiveness to some, and not with full attentiveness to others? The Buddha answers with the simile of the farmer sowing seed.

title: SN 42:8  Saṅkha Sutta | The Conch Trumpet
summary: SN 42:8  Saṅkha Sutta | The Conch Trumpet  —  The skillful way to respond to the realization that you have behaved unskillfully in the past.

title: SN 42:9  Kula Sutta | Families
summary: SN 42:9  Kula Sutta | Families  —  Why the monks go for alms even during a time of famine.

title: SN 42:10  Maṇicūḷaka Sutta | To Maṇicūḷaka
summary: SN 42:10  Maṇicūḷaka Sutta | To Maṇicūḷaka  —  Why the Buddha forbade the monks from consenting to gifts of money or from seeking money.

title: SN 42:11  Gandhabhaka Sutta | To Gandhabhaka
summary: SN 42:11  Gandhabhaka Sutta | To Gandhabhaka  —  The Buddha explains the origination and ending of stress in simple and very immediate terms.

title: SN 43  Asaṅkhata Saṁyutta | Unfabricated-Connected
summary: SN 43  Asaṅkhata Saṁyutta | Unfabricated-Connected  —  This saṁyutta provides a list of 33 names for the goal of the practice.

title: SN 44  Abyākata Saṁyutta | Undeclared-Connected
summary: SN 44  Abyākata Saṁyutta | Undeclared-Connected  —  Introduction.

title: SN 45:1  Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance
summary: SN 45:1  Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance  —  The development of the right and wrong paths explained in linear terms.

title: SN 45:2  Upaḍḍha Sutta | Half (of the Holy Life)
summary: SN 45:2  Upaḍḍha Sutta | Half (of the Holy Life)  —  The Buddha explains how and why having admirable people as friends is not just half of the holy life, but is the whole of the holy life.

title: SN 45:4  Brāhmaṇa Sutta | The Brahman
summary: SN 45:4  Brāhmaṇa Sutta | The Brahman  —  The Buddha gives an extended metaphor to explain how the noble eightfold path can be described as a “sublime vehicle,” a “Dhamma-vehicle,” and “unexcelled victory in battle.”

title: SN 45:8  Magga-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Path
summary: SN 45:8  Magga-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Path  —  The Buddha defines the factors of the noble eightfold path.

title: SN 45:27  Kumbha Sutta | A Pot
summary: SN 45:27  Kumbha Sutta | A Pot  —  How to keep the mind from getting knocked over.

title: SN 45:56  Kalyāṇa-mittatā Sutta (SN 45:56–62) | Admirable Friendship
summary: SN 45:56  Kalyāṇa-mittatā Sutta (SN 45:56–62) | Admirable Friendship  —  Various factors that are forerunners for the arising of the noble eightfold path.

title: SN 45:153  Kumbha Sutta | A Pot
summary: SN 45:153  Kumbha Sutta | A Pot  —  How to disgorge evil, unskillful qualities.

title: SN 45:154  Suka Sutta | The Spike
summary: SN 45:154  Suka Sutta | The Spike  —  Right view can cut into ignorance just as a well-aimed spike of bearded wheat or bearded barley can cut into the hand.

title: SN 45:155  Ākāsa Sutta | The Air
summary: SN 45:155  Ākāsa Sutta | The Air  —  Just as the air contains winds of many types, a person who has developed the noble eightfold path brings all the wings to awakening (bodhi-pakkhiya-dhamma) to the culmination of their development.

title: SN 45:159  Āgantukā Sutta | Guests
summary: SN 45:159  Āgantukā Sutta | Guests  —  Developing the noble eightfold path completes the duties appropriate to all four noble truths.

title: SN 45:171  Ogha Sutta | Floods
summary: SN 45:171  Ogha Sutta | Floods  —  Many discourses speak of “crossing over the flood.” This discourse lists the floods that should be crossed over, and how it should be done.

title: SN 46:1  Himavanta Sutta | The Himalayas (On the Factors for awakening)
summary: SN 46:1  Himavanta Sutta | The Himalayas (On the Factors for awakening)  —  A monk attains to greatness by being established in virtue and developing the seven factors for awakening.

title: SN 46:3  Sīla Sutta | Virtue
summary: SN 46:3  Sīla Sutta | Virtue  —  The rewards of reflecting properly on the Dhamma you have heard.

title: SN 46:4  Vattha Sutta | Clothes
summary: SN 46:4  Vattha Sutta | Clothes  —  An arahant can observe the seven factors for awakening as they arise and cease within him.

title: SN 46:5  Bhikkhu Sutta | To a Monk
summary: SN 46:5  Bhikkhu Sutta | To a Monk  —  The Buddha explains that the factors for awakening lead to awakening (and, by implication, they are not constituent factors of awakening itself).

title: SN 46:8  Upavāṇa Sutta | Upavāṇa
summary: SN 46:8  Upavāṇa Sutta | Upavāṇa  —  How a monk can know that “through appropriate attention, the seven factors for awakening, mastered in me in such a way, lead to a pleasant abiding.”

title: SN 46:11  Pāṇa Sutta | Living Beings
summary: SN 46:11  Pāṇa Sutta | Living Beings  —  To neglect the factors for awakening is to neglect the noble path.

title: SN 46:14  Gilāna Sutta | Ill
summary: SN 46:14  Gilāna Sutta | Ill  —  The development of the factors for awakening depends on the support of virtue.

title: SN 46:18  Viraddha Sutta | Neglected
summary: SN 46:18  Viraddha Sutta | Neglected  —  The Buddha helps Ven. Mahā Kassapa recover from an illness by reminding him of the factors for awakening.

title: SN 46:26  Khaya Sutta | Ending
summary: SN 46:26  Khaya Sutta | Ending  —  The practice of the factors for awakening leads to the ending of craving, the ending of action, and the ending of stress.

title: SN 46:29  Ekadhamma Sutta | One Quality
summary: SN 46:29  Ekadhamma Sutta | One Quality  —  The factors for awakening lead to the abandoning of things conducive to the fetters.

title: SN 46:30  Udāyin Sutta | To Udāyin
summary: SN 46:30  Udāyin Sutta | To Udāyin  —  Ven. Udāyin reports on how much he has benefitted from his love and respect for the Buddha, and from his sense of shame and compunction with regard to the Buddha.

title: SN 46:38  Nīvaraṇa Sutta | Hindrances
summary: SN 46:38  Nīvaraṇa Sutta | Hindrances  —  When you focus your entire awareness on listening to the Dhamma, the hindrances are absndoned and the factors for awakening are developed.

title: SN 46:51  Āhāra Sutta | Food (for the Factors for awakening)
summary: SN 46:51  Āhāra Sutta | Food (for the Factors for awakening)  —  How to feed and starve the hindrances and factors for awakening.

title: SN 46:52  Pariyāya Sutta | An Exposition
summary: SN 46:52  Pariyāya Sutta | An Exposition  —  An analysis of the hindrances and factors for awakening, showing how the five hindrances can be described as ten, and the seven factors for awakening as fourteen.

title: SN 46:53  Aggi Sutta | Fire
summary: SN 46:53  Aggi Sutta | Fire  —  Which factors for awakening should be developed in response to torpor or restlessness in the mind.

title: SN 46:54  Mettā Sutta | Goodwill
summary: SN 46:54  Mettā Sutta | Goodwill  —  How the Buddha’s instructions in the four sublime attitudes (brahma-vihāra) differ from those of other sects.

title: SN 47:4  Sālā Sutta | At Sālā
summary: SN 47:4  Sālā Sutta | At Sālā  —  Three levels of mindfulness and concentration practice: for newcomers, for those in training, and for arahants.

title: SN 47:6  Sakuṇagghi Sutta | The Hawk
summary: SN 47:6  Sakuṇagghi Sutta | The Hawk  —  The safety of wandering in your proper range as a meditator—the four establishings of mindfulness—illustrated with the simile of the hawk and the quail.

title: SN 47:7  Makkaṭa Sutta | The Monkey
summary: SN 47:7  Makkaṭa Sutta | The Monkey  —  The safety of wandering in your proper range as a meditator—the four establishings of mindfulness—illustrated with the simile of the hunter and the monkey.

title: SN 47:8  Sūda Sutta | The Cook
summary: SN 47:8  Sūda Sutta | The Cook  —  Achieve results in mindfulness practice by taking note of what leads your mind to concentration, in the same way that a skilled cook takes note of what his employer likes to eat.

title: SN 47:10  Bhikkhun’upassaya Sutta | At the Nuns’ Residence
summary: SN 47:10  Bhikkhun’upassaya Sutta | At the Nuns’ Residence  —  Mindfulness developed through directing and not directing the mind.

title: SN 47:13  Cunda Sutta | About Cunda (Ven. Sāriputta’s Passing Away)
summary: SN 47:13  Cunda Sutta | About Cunda (Ven. Sāriputta’s Passing Away)  —  The Buddha comforts Ven. Ānanda after Ven. Sāriputta’s passing away: “When he totally unbound, did Sāriputta take the aggregate of virtue… concentration… discernment… release… the aggregate of knowledge & vision of release along with him?”

title: SN 47:16  Uttiya Sutta | To Uttijya
summary: SN 47:16  Uttiya Sutta | To Uttijya  —  The practice of establishing mindfulness is based on well-purified virtue and views made straight.

title: SN 47:19  Sedaka Sutta (1) | At Sedaka (The Acrobat)
summary: SN 47:19  Sedaka Sutta (1) | At Sedaka (The Acrobat)  —  When watching after yourself, you watch after others. When watching after others, you watch after yourself.

title: SN 47:20  Sedaka Sutta (2) | At Sedaka (The Beauty Queen)
summary: SN 47:20  Sedaka Sutta (2) | At Sedaka (The Beauty Queen)  —  The parable of the man with the bowl of oil on his head, illustrating the care and attention that should be given to practicing mindfulness of the body.

title: SN 47:25  Brāhmaṇa Sutta | To a Brahman
summary: SN 47:25  Brāhmaṇa Sutta | To a Brahman  —  The practice of the four establishings of mindfulness helps the True Dhamma to last long.

title: SN 47:33  Viraddha Sutta | Neglected
summary: SN 47:33  Viraddha Sutta | Neglected  —  To neglect the four establishings of mindfulness is to neglect the noble path.

title: SN 47:35  Sata Sutta | Mindful
summary: SN 47:35  Sata Sutta | Mindful  —  What it means to be mindful and alert.

title: SN 47:37  Chanda Sutta | Desire
summary: SN 47:37  Chanda Sutta | Desire  —  By practicing the establishings of mindfulness so as to abandon desire for the frames of reference on which they are based—body, feelings, mind, mental qualities—you can realize the deathless.

title: SN 47:38  Pariññā Sutta | Comprehension
summary: SN 47:38  Pariññā Sutta | Comprehension  —  By practicing the establishings of mindfulness so as to comprehend the frames of reference on which they are based—body, feelings, mind, mental qualities—you can realize the deathless.

title: SN 47:40  Satipaṭṭhāna-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Establishings of Mindfulness
summary: SN 47:40  Satipaṭṭhāna-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Establishings of Mindfulness  —  The establishings of mindfulness, the development of the establishings of mindfulness, and the path of practice for the development of the establishings of mindfulness.

title: SN 47:41  Amata Sutta | Deathless
summary: SN 47:41  Amata Sutta | Deathless  —  If you neglect the establishings of mindfulness, you lose your opportunity for the deathless.

title: SN 47:42  Samudaya Sutta | Origination
summary: SN 47:42  Samudaya Sutta | Origination  —  The origination and the subsiding of the four frames of reference on which the establishings of mindfulness are based.

title: SN 48:3  Sota Sutta | The Stream
summary: SN 48:3  Sota Sutta | The Stream  —  The results of discerning the origination, the passing away, the allure, the drawbacks, and the escape from the five faculties of conviction, persistence, mindfulness, concentration, and discernment.

title: SN 48:4  Arahant Sutta | The Arahant
summary: SN 48:4  Arahant Sutta | The Arahant  —  The higher results of discerning the origination, the passing away, the allure, the drawbacks, and the escape from the five faculties of conviction, persistence, mindfulness, concentration, and discernment.

title: SN 48:8  Daṭṭhabbaṁ Sutta | To Be Seen
summary: SN 48:8  Daṭṭhabbaṁ Sutta | To Be Seen  —  The five faculties related to other teachings.

title: SN 48:10  Indriya-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Faculties
summary: SN 48:10  Indriya-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Faculties  —  The Buddha defines the five faculties of conviction, persistence, mindfulness, concentration, and discernment.

title: SN 48:21  Na Bhava Sutta | No Becoming
summary: SN 48:21  Na Bhava Sutta | No Becoming  —  A sutta making the same point as the famous simile of the raft: When the path arrives at awakening, it, too, has to be abandoned.

title: SN 48:38  Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis (of the Feeling Faculties) (3)
summary: SN 48:38  Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis (of the Feeling Faculties) (3)  —  The Buddha defines the five faculties of faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, distress, and equanimity.

title: SN 48:39  Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis (of the Feeling Faculties) (4)
summary: SN 48:39  Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis (of the Feeling Faculties) (4)  —  The Buddha explains how to contemplate the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, distress, and equanimity as they are based on contact.

title: SN 48:41  Jarā Sutta | Old Age
summary: SN 48:41  Jarā Sutta | Old Age  —  Even in the Buddha, as he aged, there was deterioration in his faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.

title: SN 48:44  Pubbakoṭṭhaka Sutta | Eastern Gatehouse
summary: SN 48:44  Pubbakoṭṭhaka Sutta | Eastern Gatehouse  —  Why Ven. Sāriputta didn’t take it on conviction that the faculties of conviction, persistence, mindfulness, concentration, and discernment culminate in the deathless.

title: SN 48:46  Pubbārāma Sutta | The Eastern Monastery
summary: SN 48:46  Pubbārāma Sutta | The Eastern Monastery  —  The development of two faculties—noble discernment and noble release—enables an arahant to declare knowledge of awakening.

title: SN 48:50  Saddhā Sutta | Conviction
summary: SN 48:50  Saddhā Sutta | Conviction  —  How conviction is developed into the faculty of conviction.

title: SN 48:52  Malla Sutta | Mallans
summary: SN 48:52  Malla Sutta | Mallans  —  The faculty of discernment makes the other faculties firm, just as the ridge-beam of a roof makes the rafters that support it firm.

title: SN 48:53  Sekha Sutta | The Learner
summary: SN 48:53  Sekha Sutta | The Learner  —  The standards by which stream-winners can know that they are stream-winners, and by which arahants can know they are arahants.

title: SN 48:56  Patiṭṭhita Sutta | Established
summary: SN 48:56  Patiṭṭhita Sutta | Established  —  When heedfulness is established, the five faculties of conviction, persistence, mindfulness, concentration, and discernment are developed well.

title: SN 51:13  Chanda Sutta | Desire
summary: SN 51:13  Chanda Sutta | Desire  —  The four bases of power and the fabrications of exertion defined.

title: SN 51:14  Moggallāna Sutta | Moggallāna
summary: SN 51:14  Moggallāna Sutta | Moggallāna  —  At the Buddha’s request, Ven. Moggallāna displays a feat of psychic power to bring a group of rowdy monks to their senses. The Buddha then explains to the monks the other feats that Moggallāna has mastered through his mastery of the four bases of power.

title: SN 51:15  Brahmaṇa Sutta | To Uṇṇābha the Brahman
summary: SN 51:15  Brahmaṇa Sutta | To Uṇṇābha the Brahman  —  How desire can lead to the end of desire.

title: SN 51:20  Iddhipāda-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Bases of Power
summary: SN 51:20  Iddhipāda-Vibhaṅga Sutta | An Analysis of the Bases of Power  —  A detailed analysis of how the bases of power should be developed so as to be of great fruit and great benefit.

title: SN 51:22  Ayoguḷa Sutta | The Iron Ball
summary: SN 51:22  Ayoguḷa Sutta | The Iron Ball  —  How the Buddha traveled to the Brahmā worlds.

title: SN 52:9  Ambapālī Sutta | Ambapālī
summary: SN 52:9  Ambapālī Sutta | Ambapālī  —  How Ven. Anuruddha, an arahant, meditates so that his faculties are bright.

title: SN 52:10  Gilāyana Sutta | Illness
summary: SN 52:10  Gilāyana Sutta | Illness  —  How Ven. Anuruddha, when ill, meditates so that pains do not invade his mind or remain.

title: SN 54:6  Ariṭṭha Sutta | To Ariṭṭha (On Mindfulness of Breathing)
summary: SN 54:6  Ariṭṭha Sutta | To Ariṭṭha (On Mindfulness of Breathing)  —  There is more to breath meditation than breathing mindfully while subduing desires for past and future sense pleasures, and subduing irritation for events in the present.

title: SN 54:8  Dīpa Sutta | The Lamp
summary: SN 54:8  Dīpa Sutta | The Lamp  —  The benefits to be gained by following the Buddha’s sixteen-step program for breath meditation.

title: SN 54:9  Vesālī Sutta | At Vesālī
summary: SN 54:9  Vesālī Sutta | At Vesālī  —  The story of the monks who committed suicide after contemplating the unattractiveness of the body. The Buddha explains how the sixteen steps of breath meditation can disperse any unskillful states that may arise while contemplating other meditation themes.

title: SN 54:11  Icchānaṅgala Sutta | At Icchānaṅgala
summary: SN 54:11  Icchānaṅgala Sutta | At Icchānaṅgala  —  The Buddha describes his own practice of the sixteen steps of breath meditation.

title: SN 54:13  Ānanda Sutta | To Ānanda (on Mindfulness of Breathing)
summary: SN 54:13  Ānanda Sutta | To Ānanda (on Mindfulness of Breathing)  —  The Buddha explains how the practice of the sixteen steps of breath meditation brings to completion the four establishings of mindfulness, the seven factors for awakening, and clear knowing & release.

title: SN 55:1  Rāja Sutta | The Emperor
summary: SN 55:1  Rāja Sutta | The Emperor  —  Why the fruit of stream-entry excels the fruits of being a wheel-turning monarch.

title: SN 55:5  Sāriputta Sutta | To Sāriputta
summary: SN 55:5  Sāriputta Sutta | To Sāriputta  —  Stream-entry and the factors leading to stream-entry defined.

title: SN 55:7  Veḷudvāreyya Sutta | The People of Bamboo Gate
summary: SN 55:7  Veḷudvāreyya Sutta | The People of Bamboo Gate  —  How to behave if you want to enjoy the pleasures of lay life and be reborn in heaven.

title: SN 55:21  Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (1)
summary: SN 55:21  Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (1)  —  Why a stream-winner need not fear death even if his/her mindfulness gets muddled.

title: SN 55:22  Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (2)
summary: SN 55:22  Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (2)  —  Another explanation for why a stream-winner need not fear death even if his/her mindfulness gets muddled.

title: SN 55:26  Anāthapiṇḍika Sutta | To Anāthapiṇḍika (1)
summary: SN 55:26  Anāthapiṇḍika Sutta | To Anāthapiṇḍika (1)  —  Ven. Sāriputta gives an instruction to Anāthapiṇḍika—who is ill—and Anāthapiṇḍika immediately recovers.

title: SN 55:27  Anāthapiṇḍika Sutta | To Anāthapiṇḍika (2)
summary: SN 55:27  Anāthapiṇḍika Sutta | To Anāthapiṇḍika (2)  —  Anāthapiṇḍika—who is ill—asks for Ven. Ānanda to visit him.

title: SN 55:30  Licchavi Sutta | To the Licchavi
summary: SN 55:30  Licchavi Sutta | To the Licchavi  —  The four factors of stream-entry and their rewards in future lives.

title: SN 55:31  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (1)
summary: SN 55:31  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (1)  —  The four factors of stream-entry.

title: SN 55:32  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (2)
summary: SN 55:32  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (2)  —  An alternative list of the four factors of stream-entry.

title: SN 55:33  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (3)
summary: SN 55:33  Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas (3)  —  Yet another alternative list of the four factors of stream-entry.

title: SN 55:40  Nandiya Sutta | To Nandiya
summary: SN 55:40  Nandiya Sutta | To Nandiya  —  At the end of his life, the Buddha told the assembled monks to gain consummation through heedfulness—even though the most backward of the monks there were already stream-winners. This sutta explains what it means for a stream-winner to be heedful or heedless.

title: SN 55:54  Gilāna Sutta | Ill
summary: SN 55:54  Gilāna Sutta | Ill  —  How to counsel a discerning lay follower at the time of his or her death.

title: SN 56:1  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration
summary: SN 56:1  Samādhi Sutta | Concentration  —  Concentration is needed to discern the four noble truths.

title: SN 56:2  Paṭisallāna Sutta |  Seclusion
summary: SN 56:2  Paṭisallāna Sutta |  Seclusion  —  Seclusion is needed to discern the four noble truths.

title: SN 56:11  Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta | Setting the Wheel of Dhamma in Motion
summary: SN 56:11  Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta | Setting the Wheel of Dhamma in Motion  —  The Buddha’s first sermon, in which he sets forth the four noble truths and explains that he claimed to have reached awakening only after having purified three levels of knowledge with regard to each of the four truths.

title: SN 56:20  Tatha Sutta | Real
summary: SN 56:20  Tatha Sutta | Real  —  The four noble truths are real, not unreal, without alteration.

title: SN 56:26  Mittā Sutta | Friends
summary: SN 56:26  Mittā Sutta | Friends  —  It’s an act of kindness to direct those who will listen to you toward breaking through to the four noble truths.

title: SN 56:27  Tatha Sutta | Real
summary: SN 56:27  Tatha Sutta | Real  —  The noble truths are noble because they are real.

title: SN 56:28  Loka Sutta | The Cosmos
summary: SN 56:28  Loka Sutta | The Cosmos  —  The noble truths are noble because they are taught by one who is noble.

title: SN 56:30  Gavampati Sutta | Gavampati
summary: SN 56:30  Gavampati Sutta | Gavampati  —  Whoever sees one of the four noble truths see all four of them.

title: SN 56:31  Siṁsapā Sutta | Siṁsapā Leaves
summary: SN 56:31  Siṁsapā Sutta | Siṁsapā Leaves  —  What the Buddha taught as compared to what he knew but didn’t teach.

title: SN 56:32  Khadira Sutta | Acacia
summary: SN 56:32  Khadira Sutta | Acacia  —  Bringing about the end of stress without breaking through to the four noble truths is as impossible as carrying water in a basket woven from tiny leaves.

title: SN 56:35  Sattisata Sutta | One Hundred Spears
summary: SN 56:35  Sattisata Sutta | One Hundred Spears  —  If it were possible to make an offer that you would be speared by 300 spears a day for 100 years, yet be guaranteed a realization of the four noble truths at the end of the 100 years, why it would be worthwhile to take the offer.

title: SN 56:36  Pāṇa Sutta | Animals
summary: SN 56:36  Pāṇa Sutta | Animals  —  An image for the immensity of the animal realm as a realm of deprivation, and how one can be freed from returning to that realm by contemplating the four noble truths.

title: SN 56:42  Papāta Sutta | The Drop-off
summary: SN 56:42  Papāta Sutta | The Drop-off  —  The huge and frightening drop-off that comes from reveling in fabrications, and how the drop-off can be avoided by contemplating the four noble truths.

title: SN 56:44  Kūṭa Sutta | Gabled
summary: SN 56:44  Kūṭa Sutta | Gabled  —  Bringing about the end of stress without breaking through to the four noble truths is as impossible as constructing an upper story to a building without first constructing the lower story.

title: SN 56:45  Vāla Sutta | The Horsehair
summary: SN 56:45  Vāla Sutta | The Horsehair  —  Piercing the four noble truths is more difficult than taking a horsehair split into seven strands and piercing tip with a tip.

title: SN 56:46  Andhakāra Sutta | Darkness
summary: SN 56:46  Andhakāra Sutta | Darkness  —  The intergalactic darkness is smaller and less frightening than the darkness that comes from reveling in fabrications.

title: SN 56:48  Chiggaḷa Sutta | The Hole
summary: SN 56:48  Chiggaḷa Sutta | The Hole  —  The simile of the blind turtle. The opportunity to meet with the Dhamma is extremely rare, so take advantage of it while you can.

title: SN 56:102  Paṁsu Suttas (SN 56:102–113) | Dust
summary: SN 56:102  Paṁsu Suttas (SN 56:102–113) | Dust  —  How rare it is to be reborn as a human being or a deva.
